name: Beabadoobee
description:
'''Beatrice Kristi Ilejay Laus'''{{efn|Beabadoobee was born in the Philippines. Thus, she possess her mother's maiden name which is "Ilejay",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://repertoire.bmi.com/Catalog.aspx?detail=writerid&page=1&fromrow=1&torow=25&keyid=2101751&subid=0 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20200806124546/http://repertoire.bmi.com/Catalog.aspx?detail=writerid&page=1&fromrow=1&torow=25&keyid=2101751&subid=0 |url-status=dead |archive-date=6 August 2020 |title=Songwriter/Composer: Laus, Beatrice Ilejay |work=[[Broadcast Music, Inc.]] |access-date=6 August 2020 }}</ref> while other publications have claimed her second name is "Kristi".<ref name="Trailer">{{Cite web|url=https://amirpablotraileryr13.wordpress.com/page/4/|title=Page 4|date=10 September 2017|website=Amir & Pablo Productions: Film Trailer Project|language=en|url-status=live|access-date=20 November 2019|postscript=. '''Note:''' ''Kristi featured in a film project which credits her as "Beatrice Kristi Laus".''|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191121130208/https://amirpablotraileryr13.wordpress.com/page/4/ |archive-date=21 November 2019}}</ref><ref name="Smyth">{{Cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/go/london/music/beabadoobee-interview-stephen-malkmus-a4337111.html|title=Beabadoobee interview: 'I struggled with self-acceptance – I was an anomaly'|last=Smyth|first=David|date=17 January 2020|website=[[Evening Standard]]|language=en|access-date=18 January 2020|archive-date=17 January 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200117224017/https://www.standard.co.uk/go/london/music/beabadoobee-interview-stephen-malkmus-a4337111.html|url-status=live}}</ref> She was also referred to as "Bea Regner" in her early career.<ref name="Inquirer">{{Cite news|url=https://globalnation.inquirer.net/169309/brit-fil-singer-songwriter-signs-independent-british-record-label|title=Brit-Fil singer-songwriter signs with independent British record label|last=Alcantara|first=Melissa Legarda|date=27 August 2018|newspaper=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|language=en|url-status=live|access-date=19 November 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918070152/https://globalnation.inquirer.net/169309/brit-fil-singer-songwriter-signs-independent-british-record-label|archive-date=18 September 2018}}</ref><ref name="AllMusic">{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/beabadoobee-mn0003780500/biography|title=Beabadoobee {{!}} Biography & History|last=Collar|first=Matt|website=[[AllMusic]]|language=en-us|url-status=live|access-date=19 November 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191121131733/https://www.allmusic.com/artist/beabadoobee-mn0003780500/biography|archive-date=21 November 2019}}</ref>|name=name}} (born 3 June 2000), known professionally as '''Beabadoobee''' ({{IPAc-en|b|iː|b|ə|ˈ|d|uː|b|iː}}; ''{{Respell|bee|bə|DOO|bee}}''; stylized in all lowercase), is a [[Filipino-British]] singer-songwriter. From 2018 to 2021, she released five extended plays (EPs) under the independent label [[Dirty Hit]]: ''Lice'' (2018), ''Patched Up'' (2018), ''[[Loveworm]]'' (2019), ''[[Space Cadet (EP)|Space Cadet]]'' (2019) and ''[[Our Extended Play (EP)|Our Extended Play]]'' (2021). Her debut studio album ''[[Fake It Flowers]]'' was released in October 2020, and received critical acclaim. Her second studio album, ''[[Beatopia]]'', was released on 15 July 2022, which spawned the hit "[[The Perfect Pair]]". Her third studio album, ''[[This Is How Tomorrow Moves]]'', was released on 9 August 2024; it became her first album to peak atop the [[UK Albums Chart]].

Beabadoobee served as a supporting act for labelmates [[the 1975]] during several legs of their [[Music for Cars (concert tour)|Music for Cars Tour]], as well as American singer [[Clairo]]'s [[Immunity Tour|''Immunity'' Tour]], [[Olivia Rodrigo]]’s [[Guts World Tour]] and [[Taylor Swift]]'s [[the Eras Tour]]. She was nominated for the [[Rising Star (Brit Award)|Rising Star Award]] at the [[2020 Brit Awards]], and was presented with the Radar Award at the 2020 [[NME Awards]]. Beabadoobee was also predicted as a breakthrough act for 2020 in an annual [[BBC]] poll of music critics, [[Sound of 2020]].
